title-group.article-title: The effect of pain-education nursing based on a mind map on postoperative pain score and quality of life in patients with colorectal cancer

abstract.p: Mind mapping is a combination of images and logical thinking in the form of pictures and texts. It presents a natural expression process that conforms to the divergent thinking of the brain, helping patients understand memory. This study aimed to investigate the impact of pain-education nursing with the aid of mind maps on postoperative pain scores and quality of life in patients with colorectal cancer. The medical records of 100 colorectal cancer patients treated from July 2020 to July 2022 were selected as retrospective research participants and divided into control and observation groups. The control group received routine pain care, and the observation group was given pain-education nursing based on a mind map. The effects on quality of life, pain, negative emotions, and comfort after nursing were compared between the 2 groups. There was no significant difference in quality of-life scores between the 2 groups before the nursing intervention (P > .05). After nursing, the physical, emotional, cognitive, and social functions of patients in the observation group were significantly higher than those in the control group. However, the overall quality of life and financial difficulties of patients in the observation group were significantly lower than those in the control group (P < .05). The observation group’s social, physical, and psychological comfort scores were significantly higher than those in the control group after nursing intervention (P < .05). After nursing, the observation group’s visual analog scale scores at different times after the operation were significantly lower than those of the control group. The scores on the self-rating anxiety scale and self-rating depression scale in the observation group were significantly lower than those in the control group (P < .05). Pain-education nursing based on mind maps can effectively improve the daily living ability, pain symptoms, and quality of life of patients after colorectal cancer, and there is a reference value for post-nursing care of patients after colorectal cancer.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: With the continuous improvement in people’s living standards and lifestyle changes, especially the change in dietary structure from high-fiber to low-fiber, high-fat, high-protein, and refined carbohydrates, morbidity and mortality have shown an increasing trend year by year.[1] The treatment for colorectal cancer is primarily surgery, supplemented by radiotherapy and chemotherapy, molecular targeted therapy, biological immunotherapy, and other treatment methods.[2] Surgery is still the best treatment for patients with early colorectal cancer, but even if the surgery achieves resection, the presence of residual tumor cells in the body is uncertain; therefore, adjuvant chemotherapy is still needed.[3] However, chemotherapy not only kills tumor cells but also causes damage to the body’s normal tissues, causing various accompanying symptoms and mental distress to patients and seriously reducing the patient’s quality of life.[4] If the corresponding treatment measures are not taken to intervene, they will have a series of negative effects on the patient’s follow-up treatment and recovery, including functional status, emotional state, and quality of life. Among them, gastrointestinal reactions and hand and foot syndromes were the most severe side effects.[5]

Although the patient’s trauma is minimal, postoperative catheter balloon compression to stop bleeding will lead to bladder spasm, resulting in extreme pain for the patient after surgery. Because psychological and physiological factors and humoral stress induce perioperative pain, all factors should be considered in clinical painless nursing interventions.[6] Implementing a more comprehensive painless intervention plan eases the negative psychology of patients, such as anxiety and fear, and simultaneously providing drugs, health education, and other analgesic care reduces the secretion of stress hormones in the body and the activity of pain sensitivity hormones, thereby, helps reduce the patient’s pain and encourages the perioperative patients to cooperate with nursing interventions.[7] With the transformation of the traditional biomedical model to the “physiological-psychological-social” medical model, traditional evaluation methods, such as the cure rate, survival rate, and survival time of tumors, are no longer the focus of attention.[8] Colorectal cancer can be cured through early detection, diagnosis, and treatment, but it can also be controlled through appropriate treatment, which results in a better quality of life, thereby prolonging the survival period. Therefore, improving the quality of life of patients with cancer has become an international matter. WHO defines the quality of life as the feelings and experiences of individuals in different cultures and value systems about their goals, expectations, standards, and living conditions, all the things they care about.[9] Therefore, we conducted this study to explore the effect of pain-education nursing with the aid of mind maps on the quality of life and pain scores of patients after colorectal cancer.

sec.title: 2.1. Research participants
sec.p: The medical records of 100 patients with colorectal cancer who were treated from July 2020 to July 2022 were selected as retrospective research participants and divided them into control and observation groups according to different nursing methods, with 50 cases in each group (Fig. 1). Diagnostic criteria for Colorectal Cancer:[10,11] Charcot triad characterized by abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever, or biliary acute pancreatitis. During acute exacerbation, routine blood examination showed increased white blood cell and neutrophil counts; bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and blood transaminase (ALT, AST) levels were elevated to varying degrees; and amylase and lipase were elevated in patients with acute biliary pancreatitis. Abdominal ultrasonography, CT, MRI/MRCP, or endoscopic ultrasonography suggested or suspected colorectal cancer. This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Wuhan Fourth Hospital.

caption.p: Patient allocation into the observation group and control group.

sec.title: 2.2. Inclusion and exclusion criteria
sec.p: Inclusion criteria: All elective surgery patients with complete clinical data; No intellectual or mental disorders, normal language skills, an ability to judge their own symptoms and general conditions, and no major organ dysfunction; Patients with grade 1 or higher colorectal cancer after receiving chemotherapy, accompanied by gastrointestinal side effects and negative emotions. Exclusion criteria: Patients with nerve compression symptoms due to brain metastases or limb metastases, or central or peripheral nervous system lesions due to electrolyte imbalance and other systemic diseases such as severe diabetes, who have received hormones, specific inhibitors, and other treatments, hand and foot pain not caused by chemotherapy drugs, and hand and foot ulceration; Acute pancreatitis or obstructive jaundice, abdominal surgery history, and recent drug use that affect gastrointestinal function; Those who met the inclusion criteria but did not implement the nursing intervention as planned after inclusion, and who had serious adverse reactions during the trial.

sec.title: 2.3.1. Routine pain care
sec.p: The control group implemented routine pain care, namely: Comprehensive pain assessment: the medical staff immediately screened for pain after the patient was admitted to the hospital and assessed the type and nature of the patient’s pain, pain history, pain intensity, pain location, whether there was referred pain, radiating pain, related factors of pain onset, aggravation, or relief, currently used analgesic drugs, efficacy, adverse reactions, previous analgesic methods, efficacy, adverse reactions, and important social and psychological factors; and other pain-related issues. Analgesic titration treatment was performed immediately. After analgesic treatment, each shift (an 4–8 hours interval) was used to evaluate the patient’s pain status. The treatment was based on whether the pain score exceeded 4 points. Patients were assessed and treated with analgesia at 30-minute intervals until their pain score was < 4. For patients with explosive pain, different drug evaluation times were selected according to the onset time of the drugs. The evaluation time of oral drugs was 30 to 60 minutes after drug administration, the evaluation time of intramuscular or subcutaneous injection drugs was 30 minutes after drug administration, and intravenous drug evaluation time was 30 minutes after drug administration. The evaluation time of the injected drug was 30 minutes after the drug was administered to ensure the timeliness, effectiveness, and comprehensiveness of the pain evaluation during the patient’s hospitalization. Before the patient was discharged from the hospital, the patient and family members were informed of the pain evaluation and recording methods, and the patient was instructed to record their pain; Strengthening health education: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, the responsible nurse communicated with the patient and their family members to assess their knowledge of cancer pain and to enquire about their concerns about drug treatment, such as taking medicine on time and whether there were adverse reactions. Then, during the process of handover rounds and daily treatment and nursing, corresponding pain health education was provided to the patients according to their actual situation, anytime, anywhere, so that the patients could understand the causes of their pain and master how to deal with the pain symptoms. One week after admission, a comprehensive assessment of the patients and their family members’ knowledge was conducted. If there was any doubt, pain health education was conducted again until the patients and their family members had a comprehensive understanding of cancer pain, related knowledge of its treatment, and improved patient compliance; Strengthening medication guidance: The patients were provided with excellent medication guidance, relevant treatment manuals for patients on cancer pain medication were issued, the basic principle of “3-level analgesia ladder” was followed, and the therapeutic effects of analgesic drugs were explained. For the prevention and treatment of adverse reactions, patients were instructed not to change or adjust the analgesic drugs and dosages used, and all patients received oral drug therapy. The pain follow-up was continued after discharge, and the patient’s condition was documented; Promote self-management of patients: Pain scales and precautions for the use of analgesics were posted on the walls of the ward and in front of the patient’s bed, and patients were asked to self-evaluate their pain several times a day and to inform the doctor immediately once the self-score exceeded 4 points. This was then treated by a doctor. The patients were asked to continue their own pain assessment and management after discharge. When pain occurred, they could listen to music, watch videos, walk, talk, etc, to distract their attention, or adjust the dosage according to the doctor’s advice to avoid explosive pain; Humanized ward management: A relatively quiet ward was chosen for the patient, a good ward environment was maintained, no more than 2 family members were allowed to accompany the patient, and the patient’s psychological and family support and comfort was ensured. Treatment and nursing operations were performed on patients 1 to 2 hours after drug treatment. In the process of daily nursing care, gentle nursing operations were instituted to minimize irritation and pain in patients; Prevention of adverse reactions to analgesic drugs: for patients who used opioid analgesia for the first time, they were informed that nausea, vomiting, constipation, and other gastrointestinal reactions could occur and the patient’s tolerance was assessed. Simultaneously, metoclopramide, domperidone, and other drugs were administered to prevent adverse reactions such as nausea and vomiting. Antiemetic drugs were stopped after the patient’s gradual adaptation to the drug, and symptoms such as nausea and vomiting were relieved. Those who took opioid analgesics were advised to participate in exercise, drink more water, increase dietary fiber intake, massage the abdomen, and use lactulose and other drugs simultaneously to avoid constipation. For patients with severe gastrointestinal adverse reactions, drugs such as ondansetron were used if necessary, and symptomatic treatments such as oral senna and enemas were also used.

sec.title: 2.3.2. Pain-education nursing under mind map
sec.p: The observation group implemented pain-education nursing based on mind maps of the routine pain care of the control group. The specific measures were as follows: On the day of the patient’s admission, the researcher brought the mind map to the patient’s bedside and introduced hospitalization procedures to the patients and their families according to the knowledge on the mind map. Environment, ward rules and regulations, diagnosis and treatment information, and other related content were described; emotional support was provided. One day before the operation, the researcher gradually introduced preoperative intestinal medication, self-hygiene and preparation of items to the patient according to the content of the mind map and instructed patients about the method of preoperative pulmonary function exercise, the main points of defecation training in bed, and patiently addressed the patient’s concerns to confirm whether the patient really understands the content of the plan. If necessary, the knowledge mind map was placed at the patient’s bedside for repeated reviewing by the patient; After the patient returned to the ward after the operation, the qualified nurses and postgraduates of the research group introduced the key points of getting out of bed in the early postoperative period, the drainage tube precautions, the exercise and diet guidance during the rehabilitation period, and the replacement of the ostomy bag, etc to the patient in turn with the mind map methods. During the education process, the researchers listened carefully to the patients’ problems and answered them patiently, providing psychological comfort and support to the patients and their families; Preparation for discharge and precautions after discharge: With the popularization of enhanced recovery therapy, patients with colorectal cancer in the department could generally be discharged approximately 1 week after the operation, and the doctor in charge informed them about returning to the hospital for reexamination 1 month after the operation. Therefore, the content of the third component of the education in this study was introduced by the researchers 4 to 7 days after the operation to the patients. It included the medication methods after discharge, abdominal self-assessment methods, and dietary precautions for patients with stoma through face-to-face communication with patients to analyze their cognitive situation and correct their mistakes in a targeted manner. In addition, the knowledge map is provided to patients to improve their mastery of the disease. It enables them to learn to recognize and generalize problems and to deal with them correctly. For example, learning to identify and deal with different symptoms and when to take medication, how to replace the ostomy bag, and dietary precautions so as to enhance their psychological coping ability; Cognitive reconstruction training (once per week for 2 weeks, 2 times in total) was provided to the patients by regular telephone follow-up within 1 month after discharge. First, the researchers used questions to help patients recall the information provided the first 3 times and to correct their poor cognition in a timely manner. During the follow-up process, the researchers encouraged family members to enhance their understanding and support of the patient so that they could feel their own value and enhance their desire to recover from the disease. In addition, behavioral interventions enhanced adherence to self-replacement pouches, primarily by emphasizing to patients and families the importance of a regular diet, use of common medications, and self-care and management. At the same time, patients were asked about their plans post-discharge, such as diet, medication, and exercise. After discussing the problems with the patients, they were provided with information and nursing technical support. Second, after the 4th week of discharge, the patients were reminded by telephone 3 days in advance to return to the hospital for reexamination and on agreed time. After the outpatient reexamination, the questionnaires and scales were measured again in a clinic with a suitable environment to ensure data integrity.

sec.title: 2.4. Observation indicators
sec.p: Pain was evaluated using a visual analog scale (VAS) ranging from 0 to 10, with 0 indicating no pain, 1 to 3 indicating mild pain, 4 to 6 indicating moderate pain, and 7 to 10 indicating severe pain. Cronbach α values measured before use were all >0.914. The patients completed the test independently without any internal or external factors influencing the actual situation, and the test was completed within 30 minutes; Quality of-life score: The Chinese version of the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of-Life Core Scale for Cancer Patients (European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer QLQ-C30) V3.0 was used. The scale contains 30 entries in 15 domains, including 5 functional domains of physical functioning, role functioning, cognitive functioning, emotional functioning, and social functioning; 3 symptom domains of fatigue, nausea and vomiting, and pain; 6 individual symptoms (dyspnea, appetite loss, sleep disturbance, constipation, diarrhea, and financial difficulties); and 1 overall health status domain. The overall health status domain was rated on a 7-point scale from 1 to 7, with 1 indicating “very poor,” 7 indicating “very good,” and the remaining entries on a 4-point scale, with 1 means “never,” 2 means “a little,” 3 means “some,” and 4 means “very much.” The scale was scored by adding the number of items included in each domain and dividing by the number of items included to obtain a crude score for that domain. A higher score in the functional domain and the general health status domain indicated a better functional status and quality of life, while a higher score in the symptom domain indicated more symptoms or problems of the patient and a worse quality of life. The scale has been translated into 43 languages, including Chinese, and is widely used in various countries and regions around the world, with good reliability and validity, a Cronbach’s α coefficient of 0.648 to 0.865 for each dimension, and a retest reliability of 0.611; Comfort: The comfort assessment included 3 items: social comfort, physical comfort, and psychological comfort, each with a maximum score of 100. A higher score indicates a higher level of comfort; Negative emotions: Negative emotions were evaluated using the self-rating anxiety scale (SAS) and self-rating depression scale (SDS). The SAS and SDS included 20 items and adopted a 4-level scoring system. Higher scores indicated more severe anxiety and depressive symptoms. Cronbach α coefficients of the scale were 0.816 and 0.826, respectively, indicating that the SAS and SDS scales had good reliability and validity.

sec.title: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was conducted using SPSS 25.0, and the data were arranged, entered into a computer database, and ensured completeness and accuracy by a cross-check. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used for measurement of data and expressed as mean ± standard deviation. The chi-square test was used to analyze proportional differences. All reported P values were 2-sided. Statistical significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: 3.1. Characteristics of study participants
sec.p: The characteristics of the study participants are summarized in Table 1. The observation group comprised 35 men and 15 women, with a mean age of 75.3 years and mean body mass index of 21.53 kg/m2. The control group included 36 men and 14 women, with a mean age of 76.31 years and mean body mass index of 20.94 kg/m2. With regard to educational level, the observation group had 17 with an education level of elementary school and below, 22 with a middle school level, and 11 with a college level and above, whereas the control group had 16 with an education level of elementary school and below, 24 with a middle school level, and 10 with a college level and above. There were no statistically significant intergroup differences in baseline characteristics (P > .05).

caption.p: Comparison of general data of the 2 groups.

sec.title: 3.2. Nursing comfort comparison
sec.p: Before the nursing education intervention, the nursing comfort of the 2 groups was not statistically significant (P > .05). The social, physical, and psychological comfort scores of the observation group were significantly higher than those of the control group (P < .05) after the intervention (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Comparison of nursing comfort before and after nursing between 2 groups. (A) Social comfort score. (B) Physiological comfort score. (C) Psychological comfort score.

sec.title: 3.3. Comparison of pain scores
sec.p: Before the nursing education intervention, there was no significant difference in VAS scores between the 2 groups (P > .05). After receiving nursing intervention, the VAS scores of the observation group at different times after operation were significantly lower than those of the control group (P < .05) (Fig. 3).

caption.p: Comparison of pain scores after nursing between 2 groups.

sec.title: 3.4. Quality of-life score comparison
sec.p: Before intervention, there was no significant difference in quality of-life scores between the 2 groups (P > .05). After the intervention, physical, emotional, cognitive, social, and functional roles in the observation group were significantly higher than those in the control group (P < .05). However, the financial difficulty score in the observation group was significantly lower than that in the control group (P < .05), Figure 4.

caption.p: Comparison of quality-of-life scores before and after nursing between 2 groups. (A) Physical functioning. (B) Emotional functioning. (C) Cognitive functioning. (D) Social functioning. (E) Role functioning. (F) Financial difficulties.

sec.title: 3.5. Comparison of negative emotions
sec.p: Before the intervention, there was no significant difference in SAS and SDS scores between the 2 groups (all P > .05). After the intervention, the SAS and SDS scores of the observation group were significantly lower than those of the control group (all P < .05), as shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Comparison of negative emotions between 2 groups. (A) SAS. (B) SDS. SAS = self-rating anxiety scale, SDS = self-rating depression scale.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: The mind mapping application is a new model of nurse training, which lists nursing care plans in the form of illustrations, enabling nurses to better understand and remember nursing content, grasp the focus and direction of nursing care, and prevent unclear thinking and lack of prioritization. Thus, nursing measures can be carried out effectively to ensure the implementation of the overall nursing concept.[12] Mind mapping is very helpful in developing nurses clinical critical thinking.[13] Pain-education nursing based on mind mapping has become an integral part of modern nursing. Pain-education nursing based on mind mapping improves patients awareness of self-care, enhances compliance, improves self-care capabilities, delays disease progression, and achieves rapid recovery.[14] It is an important tool for hospitals to transform from purely therapeutic services into holistic care centers focused on prevention, treatment, nursing, and rehabilitation integrated with health care, which has the advantage of low costs and high output.[15] It has become an industry consensus to vigorously conduct pain-education nursing based on mind mapping to promote hospital modernization.[16] However, only a few clinical studies have been conducted on pain-education nursing based on mind mapping in China. Therefore, in this study, we used a mind map to guide nurses in health education for patients with colorectal cancer so that nurses could explain the key points and precautions of perioperative care to patients in a more complete and detailed manner and meet the knowledge needs of patients to the greatest extent, thus improving compliance with treatment and care and reducing noncooperation and nurse-patient disputes.

In the present study, the social, physical, and psychological comfort scores of the observation group were significantly higher than those of the control group. The pain-education nursing based on mind mapping effectively improved patient comfort; when combined with conventional pain care, this process enhanced the body’s defense ability and quality of life in patients.[17] Patients with colorectal cancer may experience marked pain during treatment due to related lesions and the anticancer treatment process.[18] Patients experience decreased appetite, reduced resistance, and sleep disorders that greatly impact their quality of life.[19] Poor pain control not only increases the incidence of anxiety and depression but also reduces treatment confidence and compliance, which directly affects prognosis.[20] Pain-education nursing based on mind mapping applies to all disciplines, and the patient can be fully counseled through this system and the most suitable scientific and reasonable comprehensive treatment plan for the patient’s condition can be formulated.[21] The best outcome for the patient is achieved while ensuring medical safety.[22] The pain-education nursing model, based on mind mapping, adjusts the psychological state of the patients, provides timely health education, and guides patients in medication use.[23] By ensuring that patients can consume adequate nutrition and regularly analyze their health status for treatment, they are able to adjust their plans and carry out targeted care promptly and are also responsible for postoperative rehabilitation and self-life recovery exercises.[24] Pharmacological analgesia, as the main modality for the treatment of colorectal cancer pain, has formed a 3-step analgesic treatment principle.[25–28] However, a large number of studies have found that the therapeutic effect of long-term analgesic drugs is not ideal, and the incidence of adverse reactions in patients after treatment is relatively high, which not only affects the clinical treatment but also has a great impact on the quality of life of patients.[29] The use of mind mapping in the health education of cancer patients to evaluate the level of pain, medication compliance, and patient satisfaction has enabled patients to control their pain and acquire knowledge about medication after the intervention.[30,31]

Our nursing intervention improved the patient’s physical and emotional functions, indicating that appropriate TCM nursing methods can improve patients moods and resolve their psychological problems. During the first survey before the intervention, it was found that some patients attributed their bad mood to the tumor, economic burdens, and the toxic side effects of chemotherapy, which caused somatic lesions and a heavy psychological burden.[32–34] Therefore, mood, as a subjective experience, is also influenced by the toxic side effects of chemotherapy.[35] Actively managing the side effects of chemotherapy can effectively improve the quality of life of chemotherapy patients with colorectal cancer.[36–39]

This study had some limitations. Data were collected from only 1 hospital, and because of the limited time, effective follow-up of patients long-term healing was not possible. The impact of cancer staging on the patient’s quality of life was not considered because of the low number of reports in the literature.

In conclusion, pain-education nursing based on mind maps can effectively improve the daily life of colorectal cancer patients, adequately improve patients pain symptoms and quality of life, and have a certain reference value for the after-care of patients after colorectal cancer.
